next_steps.note: "Brainstorm potential themes or subjects for the poetry (e.g., nature, love, loss, social commentary). Add 3-5 to the 'Ideas' list.",
"Research contemporary poets and poetry styles to identify potential influences and inspiration. Add 2-3 poets/styles to the 'Ideas' list.",
"Draft a short poem (8-12 lines) focused on one of the brainstormed themes.  Add to 'Progress' as 'First Draft - [Theme]'.",
"Establish a feedback mechanism - identify 1-2 individuals willing to review drafts and provide constructive criticism. Document in 'Issues' if finding reviewers proves difficult.",
"Define a target length or collection size for the overall poetry project (e.g., a chapbook of 10 poems, a series of sonnets). Document the defined scope in 'Progress'."
"Brainstorm 3 potential themes or concepts for the next poem, adding them to the 'Ideas' list.",
"Review existing 'Ideas' list and select *one* poem concept to begin drafting; define a rough structure (e.g., free verse, sonnet, haiku).",
"Write the first draft of the selected poem - aim for completion, even if rough, and add to 'Progress' as 'First Draft Complete'.",
"Identify one potential issue with the project (e.g., writer's block, lack of inspiration) and add it to the 'Issues' list.",
"Research a poet whose style aligns with the desired aesthetic for this project and note 3 specific techniques to potentially emulate."
"Begin the 'Poetry Prompt Jar' exercise: create a digital or physical jar with at least 10 unique prompts and commit to drawing one each day for the next week.",
"Choose a source for the 'Found Poetry' exercise (newspaper, magazine, website) and spend 30 minutes 'mining' it for poetic fragments.",
"Select a poem significantly different from your usual style and begin the 'Style Swap' challenge - rewrite the first stanza in a traditional form.",
"Reach out to a fellow writer to propose a 'Collaborative Line' poem - establish a basic starting line and agree on a collaborative process.",
"Choose an everyday object and complete the 'Sensory Detail Inventory' exercise - aim for at least 20 detailed sensory observations."

ideas.note: "**'Poetry Prompt Jar':** Create a physical or digital 'jar' filled with unique prompts – single words, images, lines from other poems, unusual scenarios – to spark immediate creative inspiration when facing writer's block. Commit to drawing one prompt each day for the next week.",

"**'Found Poetry' Exercise:** Collect text from newspapers, magazines, or online sources and 'mine' it for poetic lines/phrases. Arrange these fragments into a new poem, embracing the unexpected juxtapositions. This can break creative ruts and introduce new vocabulary/themes.",

"**'Style Swap' Challenge:** Choose a poem from a genre *completely* different from your preferred style (e.g., a rap lyric, a legal document). Rewrite it as a traditional poetic form (sonnet, haiku, etc.). This forces you to think about poetic structure in a new way.",

"**'Collaborative Line' Project:**  Connect with another writer (online or in-person) and begin a poem by each contributing one line at a time, building it organically.  Set a rule to avoid pre-planning; embrace the unexpected turns.",

"**'Sensory Detail Inventory':**  Choose a single everyday object (a coffee mug, a houseplant, a street sign). Spend 15 minutes writing down *only* sensory details about it – what it looks, sounds, smells, feels, and even 'tastes' like (metaphorically). Use this detailed inventory to build a poem focused on observation."
